sp.p: Well, without that it come ſo to paſſe that you do ſée the childe with your owne eies, nothing will hinder the courſe of this marriage.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What ſayeſt thou? when thou once vnderſtoodeſt that they purpoſed ſuch a matter, why didſt thou not than preſently tell it vnto Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why than, who els hath withdrawen him from theſe harlots but my ſelfe? for certeynly we all know how excéedingly he loued this woman. Now he is deſirous to haue a wife, and as for that matter, let mée alone withall: yet neuertheleſſe go you on forward ſtill with this marriage as you doo: and I hope God will proſper it.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p:
Very well, go thy waies in, ſtay there till I come: and prouide what is néedfull.
Dauus being gon in, Simo turne his tale to the audiens. He could not driue it into my head, to make me beléeue all this, neither am I certaine whether all that hée told me be true or no: But I paſſe not greatly for that. Marry the matter I ſtand moſt vpon, is the promiſe which my ſonne himſelfe made vnto me: Now will I go méete with Chremes:
I will intreate him for his daughter to my ſonne in marryage, and if I doo obteine her, why ſhould I make any more daying for the matter, but marry them out of the way? for as touching my ſonnes promiſe, I haue no doubt at all, if hée ſhall refuſe to performe it, but I may full rightly compel him to it. But lo yonder where Chremes himſelfe comes towards mée, euen in as good time as may be.

div.head: ¶Act. 3. Scen. 3.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: In this ſcene, by meanes of Chremes and Simo meeting together, the fained marriage is become a marriage in good earneſt.

div.stage:
Simo,
and Chremes,
the old men.

sp.p: GOD ſaue you neighbour Chremes.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O ſir, you are the onely man I ſought.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And I you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: You com as wel as I could wiſh: There haue ſome bin with me, which told me they heard you ſay that my daughter ſhould this day be marryed to your ſonne: Now the matter I come for, is to ſée, whether you, or they, do dote.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Heare me a word, or twoo, and you ſhall ſoone know both what I deſire of you, and alſo what you require of me.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: I heare you, go too, ſpeake your minde.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p:
Chremes I beſéech you for Gods ſake, and for our frendſhips ſake begun betwixt vs from our childehood, and growen together with our years: I beſeech you as you loue your onely daughter, & as you tender my ſon,
whome it lieth in you chéefely to ſaue or to ſpill, yt you will help me now in this matter, and like as the marriage ſhould haue bin, that ſo now, it may be made vp betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Chre.
sp.p: Tuſh, neuer pray mée ſo much, as though you could not obteine this at my hands but by much praying: Doo you think mée now an other manner of man, than I was then, when I promiſed my daughter vnto you? If it be a matter profitable for both parts, that this marriage be made, then cauſe hir furthwith to be ſent for. But if there grow of this, more harme than good, as well to the one as to the other: Then my deſire is, that you will conſider of the matter indifferently for both parts, euen no otherwiſe than if ſhe were your daughter, and that I were father vnto Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea Chremes, euen ſo is my meaning, and therfore doo I requeſt that it may be effected. Neither would I requeſt it at your hands, if the matter if ſelfe dyd not geue me good occaſion.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What may that be?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Mary ſir, my ſonne and Glycerie are fallen out.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I heare you.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay, but ſo far fallen out, as I hope they may be quite ſet a ſunder.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Tuſh, it is but a Tale.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay, without dowt it is as I ſay.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yea forſooth, thus, as I ſhall tell you, The falling out of Louers, is a Renewing of Loue.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Alas, I pray you then, let vs now preuent that, while time is, and while his hot loue is alaid with bitter words: Let vs couple him to a wife, before that this naughtie parks ſhrewd crafts, and fained teares, doo woork againe his loueſick minde, vnto pitie and compaſſion: I hope (Chremes) that being once reclaimed, by meanes of good company and honeſt wedlock, he will afterward, wt cas, winde himſelf out of theſe miſchéefs.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: It ſéemes ſo to you, but I think it neither poſſible for him to continue with this wife, nor yet for me to be able to endure it.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: How can you know that, vntill you haue made tryall of it?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yea mary, but it is a ſhrewd matter to make that Tryall vpon my daughter.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Well yet, the very worſt and vttermoſt of all, can be but a diuorſe or ſeperation, if any ſuch matter ſhould happen, as God forbyd it ſhould: But contrariwiſe, if by this meanes he doo amend and become a new man, ſée than how many commodities enſue: Firſt and formoſt, you ſhall reſtore to your fréend his ſonne: next, you ſhall finde a ſure ſonne in law to your ſelfe, and laſtly, a ſtayed huſband to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What? ſay you ſo? If you be perſwaded that this is expedient, I for my part, will not haue you hindred of any good turne that I may affoord you.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Chremes, not without good cauſe haue I alwaies ſet moſt ſtore by you of any man.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But what ſayd you erewhile?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How came you to know, that they be at iarre betwéene themſelues?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Euen Dauus himſelfe, the chéefe of their priuie Councell, dyd tell it me. And he likewiſe perſwades me to haſten this marriage, as much as I may: Think you he would haue done this, vnleſſe he were ſure that my ſonne deſires the ſame? You ſhall heare him your ſelfe, by and by. Holo ſirs, call me out Dauus hither. But ſée yonder where he comes furth of him ſelfe.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: Dauus fawning vppon the olde man, dooth perſwade him to make vp the marriage, little thinking that it ſhould come to paſſe in deede: But whē he perceiueth that Simo deales in good earneſt with Chremes as touching his daughter: he is then much perplexed, and cleane beſide himſelfe.

sp.p: I was comming to you.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: well, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why is not the bryde ſent for? it waxeth now very late.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Simo ſaith this ſoftly to Chremes. Doo you not héere him. Well Dauus, I ſtood ſomewhat in feare of thée erewhile, leaſt thou (as the common ſort of ſeruants are wont) ſhouldſt by craft and knauery haue deceyued me, in reſpect that my ſonne is in loue.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Alas ſir, ſhould I haue don ſuch a déede?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I was of that beléefe, and therefore fearing ſuch a matter, I kept ſecret from my ſonne and thée, that which now I will tell thée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt know, for now in a manner, I begin to haue ſome truſt in thée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: At laſt then, you know what manner of man I am.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: This marriage, was not meant to haue bin made indéede.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, was it not?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: No, but I fayned it of purpoſe, that I might thoroughlie trye you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, is it true ſir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: It is euen ſo as I tell thée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Sée, I could neuer perceyue ſo muche. O notable pollicie.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay but liſten to me, as ſoone as I bade thée go hence in, this man met me in excellent good time.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Dauus ſaith this ſoftly to himſelfe. Out alas, are we not cleane caſt a way?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I ſhew him all that thou toldſt me erewhile.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And this like wiſe to himſelfe. What is this I héere?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I entreat him for his daughter, and with much a doo I obtaine her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I am vtterly vndon.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Hah, what ſayeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I ſay it is excellently well don.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now is there no let or delay on this mans behalfe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I will ſtraight goe hence to byd euery thing be made redy, and ſo bring woord hither againe.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now Dauus I pray thée, ſith thou alone haſt brought this marriage for mée to paſſe:

sp.speaker: (Da.
sp.p: Yea truly, I, and none elſe.)

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: That thou wilt yet moreouer labour my ſonnes amendment.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: In déede I will doo what I can.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thou maiſt now well do it, eſpecially while he is netteled at the heart.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, ſet your minde at reſt.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Go to then, But where is he now?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: It is maruaile if he be not at home.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Simo departeth and Dauus ſtayeth ſtill. I will go to him, and tell him my minde in the ſame ſort, as I told it thée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
I am a forlorne creature, what ſhall kéepe me but that I muſt go hence ſtreight into the grinding houſe to priſon? No prayer or intreaty wil ſerue, I haue now brought all out of frame: I haue deceyued my maſter: I haue forced a marriage on my Maſters ſonne: I was the cauſe yt the marriage ſhal be made to day, euen quite vnhoped for of ye old man, & cleane contrary to the minde of Pamphilus. Sée theſe goodly crafts of mine: had I not
buſied my ſelfe, there had hapned no harme at all:
Dauus eſpieth Pamphilus comming. But lo yonder I ſée him himſelfe, I am but a dead ma •… : I would to God héere were ſome place, where I •… ight throwe my ſelfe downe headlong.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: PAMPHILVS takes on very much, that by following the deceitfull deuiſe of Dauus, he made aunſwere to his father that he would marry.

sp.p: WHere is that ſame miſchéeuous varlet, which hath cleane vndon mée?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now Lord haue mercy vpon mée.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: And yet I confeſſe, this that hath hapned, is euen good enough for mée, when I would bée ſo ſottiſh, and ſo very a dolt, as to commit my whole eſtate and welfare vnto a prating villaine. Therefore I reape a iuſt reward for my folly. But he ſhal neuer ſcape ſcotfrée with it.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This he ſaith out of Pamphilus hearing. I am ſure to bée ſafe enough for euer hereafter, if I may but now auoide this miſchéefe.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: But what may I now ſay to my father? ſhal I now refuſe marriage, and yet promiſed erewhile that I would marry? with what face dare I doo that? I wot not what to doo with my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Dauus ſpeaketh all this out of Pamphilus hearing. Truely nor I neither, what to doo with my ſelf: yet this is it I am fully reſolued vpon, I will tell him that I ſhall preſently finde out ſome remedy, and ſo put of my puniſhment yet a little while.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now hée ſées mée.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Come hither you honeſt man: how ſay you ſirra, ſée you not how I (poore ſoule) am beſtad by meanes of your deuiſes?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: But I will remedy it by and by.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Wilt thou remedy it?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes certainly maiſter Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yes, euen as thou didſt of late.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay rather better, I hope.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: O, ſhould I credit thée vile hangman? canſt thou recouer a matter full of trouble, and paſt all hope of helpe? Out alas, what a ſure ſtay had I of thée, who this day, out of my greateſt quietnes, haſt forced mée into a marriage ſpite of my téeth? did I not tell thee it would come thus to paſſe?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You did ſo.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What then art thou woorthy of?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Hanging. But yet ſuffer mée a litle to come to my ſelfe, I will ſtraight way ſéeke out ſome helpe.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Alas that I haue not leyſure to puniſh thée as I would: it is now time for mée to ſée to my ſelfe, and not to be auenged of thée.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: This ſcene doth cheefly containe the angry ſpeeches of Carinus againſt Pamphilus.

sp.p: IS this a thing credible, or worthy to be ſpoken of, that there ſhold be ſomuch peruerſneſſe in any man, as to delight in euill, and to ſéeke his owne commoditie, euen by the diſcommodity of an other? Is this kinde of people to be truſted? Nay certainely, thoſe are the very worſt kinde of people, who are ſomewhat ſhamefaſt in denying a Requeſt, but afterward, when time requires performance of their promiſes, Then of neceſſitie, they bewray themſelues and faulter, and yet the matter it ſelfe driues them then to a flat denyall: Then is their ſpéech void of all ſhame and honeſty, as thus: who are you ſir? What friend of mine are you? why ſhould you deſire my ſwéete hart? O ſir, heare you me, I loue you well, but my ſelfe better. Neuertheleſſe, if you aſke where is truth and truſtines of promis, they are neuer a whit aſhamed. Now they are not a frayd to deny, when as they ought to performe: And yet are they then afrayd, when they ſhold not. But what ſhall I doo? Is it beſt that I goe to him, to taunt and take him vp for this iniurie? I ſhall giue him ſhrewd woords his fill: But one may ſay to me, thou ſhalt be neuer the néere: yes very much: without doubt I ſhall anger euerie vayne in his hart, and withall ſhall eaſe mine owne minde.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Carinus, I haue vnawares (without God help vs) euen cleane caſt away both you and my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yea, vnawares: is it ſo indéede? Now at laſt you haue got an excuſe: Tuſh, thou haſt broken thy faith and promis.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Why, what excuſe now at laſt?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, woldſt thou yet againe deceiue me now, with thoſe ſuttle ſpéeches of thine?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter with you now?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Mary after I had told you that I was in loue with Philumena, forſooth it pleaſed you to like her well for your ſelfe: Wo is me wofull wretch, who eſtéemed the honeſty of thy minde by mine owne.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: You miſtake the matter.

sp.speaker: Car.
Pamph.
sp.p: Shold I take her? Alack, ful little do you know, in how great troobles I am wrapt, vnhappie man that I am: and what care and anguiſh, this my Tormentor hath put me to, with his deuiſes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why, is that ſuch a marueill? he takes enſample by you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Well, you would not ſay this, if you knew either me, or my loue.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I know you were at words with your father of late, and that is the matter he is now diſpleaſed with you, but yet he could not cōpel you to marry her to day.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yea and by how much the more you are ignorant of my heauines: This ſame marriage was not meant or intended for me, neither did any man motion, now at this time, to procure a wife for me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I wot well, you are compeld to it euen of your owne frée will.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Abide, you wot not yet how the caſe ſtands.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes certainely, I wot full well that you will marry her.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Why do you thus kil my hart? heare me what I ſhall ſay to you: he neuer ceaſſed, preaſſing, perſwading, and praying me ſo long, till at laſt he inforced me to ſay vnto my father, that I would marry her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What man did this?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Dauus.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, Dauus?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yea, hée brought all out of ſquare.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wherefore did hée ſo?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I wot not in the world, without that God were highly offended with mée, in that I followed his counſaile.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Dauus, Didſt thou doo this?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hah, what ſayeſt thou villayne? Now I pray God geue thee a miſchéeuous end as thou haſt deſerued. Why I pray thee tell me, if all the enemies hée hath in the world would haue wiſhed to force a marryage vpon him, what other counſaile could they haue geuen him than this?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, I am deceiued, but not diſcouraged.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ironice. I know it well.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: The matter came not well to paſſe this way, now wee will take an other courſe, vnleſſe you be of opinion, that bycauſe it had ill ſucceſſe at the firſt: that therfore this euill may not now be remedied at the laſt.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Yes mary may it, for I verily beleeue if thou doo bend thy whole indeuor vnto it, thou wilt make for me two marriages of one.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Maiſter Pamphilus, this I owe vnto you of duty, as being your ſeruaunt: euen day and night to labours to my vttermoſt with might and maine, and to hazard my life to doo you good withall: it is your part, if ought hath hapned otherwiſe than was looked for, to pardon mée. Be it that my doings proſper not: Why yet I doo my true intent: Or finde you ſome better remedy your ſelfe, and let not mée either make or meddle withall.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: That is it I deſire: ſet mée againe in the ſame ſtate thou foundeſt me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: But it muſt be don by and by.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Alas, but yet ſtay a little, Glyceries doore creaks.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: That is nothing to thée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yet I would know.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What, ſtill more ſtaying?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, I will preſently finde you out a deuiſe for this.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: HEERE Pamphilus makes promis vnto Myſis that he will neuer forſake Glycerie: yea though he ſhall procure all men to be his enimies for it.

sp.p: WHereſoeuer your friend Pamphilus be, I wil furthwith ſéeke him out, and bring him with me: In the meane time (dere hart) doo not you vexe your ſelfe with thought.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Myſis?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Who is there? O maſter Pamphilus, you méete me in very good time.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What is the matter with thée?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: My miſtres bad me pray you for Gods ſake, if you loue her, that you will come to her, now out of hand. She ſaith that ſhe longs much to ſée you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p:
Out alas, I am a forlorne man? This miſchéefe beginnes now againe a freſh: Is it méete that both I and ſhe (ſilly ſoules) ſhould be thus vexed and diſquieted
thorough thy meanes? for dowtles that is the cauſe ſhe now ſends for mée, hauing vnderſtood of the marriage I am towards.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Concerning which matter truly, full eaſily mought we haue bin at quiet, if this knaue had not buſted himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go too, if he be not mad enough of himſelfe, doo thou pricke him forward.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Truly forſooth, and euen that is the cauſe that the woefull woman is in ſorrow for.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Myſis I ſweare to thée by all the Gods, that I will neuer forſake her, no not if I wiſt, I ſhould haue all men liuing myne enemies for it. I haue deſired this woman in my hart: Shée is fallen to my lot: wée are alike in manners and condition: farewel they, that would ſet vs two a ſunder. There ſhall none part her from me, but onely death.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am now come to my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: No not the anſweare of God Apollo can be truer than this. Mary I would faine (if it may bée) that my father ſhall not thinke, that I withſtood the going forward of this marriage: But if it may not bée, then will I go the plaine way to woork, that he may thinke that I did withſtand it. What manner of man do I ſeeme?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Euen as forlorn a creature as my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I ſéeke for counſaile.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou art a valiant man.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Dauus I know whereabout thou goeſt.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Wel, certeinly I will bring this to paſſe for you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: It is more than time it were don.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I haue it but euen now to doo.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: That thou deceiue not thy ſelfe, I haue it for this mans behoofe, and not for thyne.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That is ſufficient for me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Tell mée I pray thée, what is that thou wilt doo?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I feare me, this day will ſkant ſerue me to doo my buſines: Thinke not than, that I am now at leiſure to diſcourſe: Therefore get yée both away hence, for yée doo but trouble mée.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I will go ſée Glycerie.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And what will you? whither away hence?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wilt thou haue me ſay the truth?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay, now he begins to tell me ſome long tale.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But what ſhall become of mée?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why thou ſhameles man, is it not well for thée, that I gayne thée one litle dayes reſpite, in that I doo prolong his marriage?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Dauus, yet notwithſtanding.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That I may attaine to marry her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Sée a foole.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, looke thou come hither to me, if ſo hée thou mayſt doo any good in the matter.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: To what end ſhall I come? I can do nothing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But yet if thou may doo ought.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, go too, I will come.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yf thou maiſt doo any thing, thou ſhalt finde me at home.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Now he ſpeaketh to Myſis.
Myſis doo thou ſtay here a little for mée, till I come furth againe.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: For a thing that muſt néedes be don.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Hye thee apace.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I tell thée, I will bée here againe by and by.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: DAVVS brings the childe before Simoes doore, to thend to driue Chremes backe from accompliſhing the marriage. And this ſcene conſiſts more in geſture, then in vtterance.

sp.p: WHat, can one be ſure of nothing in this world? O Lord God, I ſtill thought, that this Pamphilus was my miſtres chéefeſt ioy, as being her frend, her louer, her huſband, and one ready to ſerue her turne in all aſſayes. But now (alack forlorne woman,) what gréefe takes ſhe for his ſake? without doubt there is more harme in this, than there was good in the other. But lo, Dauus comes furth. Abide fellow, what is that, I pray thée? whither away carrieſt thou the childe?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Myſis, now muſt I néeds haue thée ſhew thy ready wit and cunning in this matter.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Where about goeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Take this ſame childe of me quickly, and lay it downe before our doore.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What I pray thée, on the bare ground?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Take thée ſome herbes of this alter, and ſtraw vnder it.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: And why doeſt not thou doo it thy ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Bycauſe if perhaps I ſhall be driuen to ſweare to my maiſter, that I layd it not there: That then I
may ſweare with a ſafe conſcience.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I perceiue you. But yet tell me, I pray thée, how is it come vpon thee to be ſo holy now of late?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go too, beſtir thée, that thou mayeſt know further of my minde, what I will doo. O good Lord.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why, what now?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: The Brides father is come, and hath preuented me. Now I leaue of my purpoſe which I firſt entended.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I wot not what thou ſayeſt.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will now make as though I came this other way on the right hand: Sée that thou bée ready to anſweare and vphold my talke, in euery point as ſhall bée néedfull.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I perceiue not at all, what thou intendeſt to doo. But if there bée any thing that my helpe may ſtand you in ſteade, or that thou ſée further into the matter than I doo: I will ſtay here, leaſt you ſhould be hindered of any benefite by my default.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: CHREMES heareth that Glycerie hath a childe by Pamphilus, and withall that ſhee is a free borne woman of Athens: by which meanes, he is quite withdrawen from the marriage.

sp.p: NOw that I haue made all things in a readines for my daughters marriage, I am come againe that I may cauſe her to be ſent for. But what haue we here? In good faith it is a childe: woman didſt thou lay this ſame childe here?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: She lookes after Dauus. Whether is this fellow gon?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What, wilt thou not aunſwere me?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Alack he is no where in ſight, wo is me (poore wench) the fellow is gon his waies, and left me here.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now Dauus comes a long. Good Lord of heauen, what hurleburley is yonder at the market? how much people is there at ſtrife? without it be that corne be at a high price, I wot not in the world what to make of it.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I pray you ſirra, why did you leaue me here all alone?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: How now, what tale is this of a roſted horſe? Nay but heareſt thou me Myſis, whoſe childe is this? or who brought it hether?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Art thou well in thy wits, that aſkeſt me this queſtion?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Whom then ſhould I aſke, ſéeing here is no body els?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This he ſaith to himſelfe. Chremes muſt be ſuppoſed to ſtand a loof liſtening vnto all the talke betweene Dauus and Myſis, and yet not ſhewing himſelfe vnto them, but vppon occaſion of their talke he oftimes vttereth ſpeaches as to himſelfe. I marueil whence it ſhould be?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Wilt thou not tell me what I aſke?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Ahlas.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Come thy way hither on my right hand.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Thou raueſt, dydſt not thou thy ſelfe?—

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Huſht, be not ſo hard for thy eares as to ſpeake one word more than I ſhall aſke thée.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Thou rayleſt.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Whence is this childe? ſpeake out aloud.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: From among you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, it is a wonder no doubt, if a hoore play a ſhameles parte.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He ſpeakes this to himſelfe This maid belongs to her of Andros for ought I can perceiue.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Doo we ſéeme ſuch fit copesmates for you to mock and dally withall?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To himſelfe. I came in time.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Beſtur thée quickly, and take a way the childe hence from the doore.
This, Dauus ſpeakes in a lower voice, that Chremes may not here him. Abide ſtill, ſée thou ſtur not a foote out of the place thou ſtandſt in.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I pray God a very vengeance light on thée, that ſo doſt terrifie me, poore wretch that I am.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Doo I ſpeake to thée or not?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And doſt thou yet aſke me what? I pray the whoſe childe haſt thou laid here? Tel me.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Doſt not thou know?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This he ſpeaketh ſoftly vnto her. Let paſſe what I know, and tell me what I aſke.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: It is yours among you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Which of vs oweth it?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This hee repeats alowd bycauſe Chremes may heare him. Hah, what ſaydſt thou? Is it Pamphilus childe?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why I pray thée and is it not?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To him ſelf. I ſée I did wel alwaies to ſhun this ſame marriage.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: O notable prank worthie of puniſhment.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What exclaming makeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why, did not I ſée this ſame child brought vnto you yeſterday in the euening?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: O thou braſen faaſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Dauus vrgeth Myſis to proue plainely that the child is borne of Glycerie, leaſt otherwiſe Chremes ſhould imagin it to be a fayned matter, as Simo doth. Act. 3. Scen. 1. At leaſt I ſaw Gammar Canthara with her clothes tuckt about her, carrying ſomewhat in her lap.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p:
In good faith yet I thank GOD with all my hart,
that there were ſome frée women of the citie, at my miſtres deliuerance.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Without doubt ſhe knewe not him, for whoſe cauſe ſhe takes this matter in hand. If Chremes ſhall ſée this ſame childe, layd héere before the doore, then will he not giue his daughter in marriage: Ah, in good ſooth he will giue her ſomuch the ſooner.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Meaning by him ſelfe. But in good ſooth he will not.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now be thou well aſſured of this, that if thou do not take awaie the childe, I will by and by ſpurn it into the midſt of the ſtrete, where I will trample thée alſo in the durt.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: In good ſadneſſe fellow, thou art not well in thy wits.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: One deceitfull deuiſe bringes an other to light: I heare now ſuch whiſpering among them, that this ſame Glycerie is frée borne of Athens.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Chremes ſpeakes ſtill to himſelfe. What is this?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So as he ſhall be driuen by law to marry her.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why I pray thée, and is ſhe not frée of this Citie indéede?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I ſée I was well nigh fallen into a ſhrewd ſporting game vnawares.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who talketh here? O Chremes, you come, in as good time as may be: heare me what I ſhall ſay.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I haue heard euery word alredy.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, haue you hard all this talke?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I tell thee I hard all from the beginning.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I pray you and haue you hard it in déede? fye, out vppon theſe lewd pranks: Now ſhould this ſame queane be had hence into Bridewell. This ſame is the man thou doſt mock: think not then, that thou mockeſt Dauus.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Alas for me vnhappy wench that I am: In good ſooth, olde father, I haue tolde nothing but truth.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I know the whole matter already: but is Simo within.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: It ſeems that Dauus offereth to d • ly and play with Myſis, ſeeking thereby to pleaſe her: and ſhee wil not abide him. Touch me not thou varlet. By God if I tell not all this vnto Glicerie, [neuer credit me.]

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why thou fooliſh wench, thou perceiueſt not what is don.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What ſhould I perceiue?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: This man is the brides father: it might not otherwiſe be compaſſed, to make him vnderſtād theſe things that we would haue him.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Why then, thou ſhouldſt haue told me ſo before.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I pray thée now, and doſt thou thinke but ſmall difference betwéene that, that one doth in good earneſt, and that which is done for the nones.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: CRITO comming from Andres to Athens, enquireth whether Glycerie haue found out who be her parents or no: and vnderſtanding that ſhe hath not yet found them, hee is therewith much greeued, bycauſe that matter doth hinder his enioying of the goods fallen vnto him by Glyceries death.

sp.p:
IT was tolde me, that héere in this ſtréete, dwelt Chryſis, who choſe rather in this town to gather goods with diſhoneſty, than to lead an honeſt poore life, in her owne countrey. By whoſe death, thoſe ſame goods, by right of law, are come to me. But I ſée now of whom I may
enquire. God ſpéede you.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: I pray you whom doo I ſée? Is not this Crito, coſin germain to Chryſis? it is euen he.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: O Myſis, God ſaue you.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: And you too good Crito.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Alack for pity, and is Chryſis dead indéede?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Yea truly forſooth, we poore ſoules are vndon by hir death.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Why, what do you? how goeth the world with you here, all well?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: What we? Truly (as the prouerb goeth) Wee doo as wee may, ſith wee may not as wee would.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How fares Glycerie, hath ſhe found out yet who be her parents here?

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: Would God ſhe had.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Why than, & hath ſhe not yet? Than in an il howre am I come hether. For in good faith if I had knowen this, I would neuer haue ſet foot forward in this iourney. For ſhe hath euer bin held and reputed for Chryſis own ſiſter. She is in preſent poſſeſſion of al that ye other had. And now, for me a ſtranger to go follow ſutes and brables in law, how eaſy and profitable a matter were that for me here to doo, euen the examples of others doo foreſhew me. Beſides that, I cannot but thinke, that ſhe hath now ſome frend and defender, for ſhe was of méetely good age and ſtature, when ſhe went from vs. I ſhould be exclaimed vpon to bée a beggerly fogger, gréedily hunting after heritage. And moreouer, it were no reaſon to ſpoyle her of that ſhe hath.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: O Gaffar Crito, in good ſooth full well doſt thou kéepe thy old wont ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well, ſith I am come hether, bring me to her, that I may yet ſée her.

sp.speaker: My.
sp.p: With a very-good will.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will follow theſe, but I would not for any thing, that the old man ſhould now ſée me.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: SIMO earneſtly deſireth to effect the marriage: Chremes on the other ſide vtterly renounceth Pamphilus for his ſonne in law, bycauſe hee hath a childe by Glycerie.

sp.p: WEL neighbour Simo, you haue now had tryall enough and enough againe, of my loue and frendſhip towards you. I began to enter into daunger far enough for you. Now at length ceaſe your entreating: for whyle I bent my ſelfe to follow your fancie, I had well nigh caſt away my doughter.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay rather (neighbour Chremes) I moſt inſtantly requeſt and beſeech you, that you will now performe in déede, the good turne that ere whyle you promiſed me on your woord.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: See how vnreaſonable you are, reſpecting your owne deſire: ſo you may bring to paſſe what you would haue, you neither regard a meane in courteſie, nor yet conſider what you requeſt at my hands: for if you did, you would (now at laſt) geue ouer to ſurcharge mee with your vnreaſonablenes.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: With what vnreaſonablenes?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
Why, & do you aſke me with what? mary ſir, you enforced me thus far, that to a looſe young man entangled
in loue with a ſtrange harlot, and vtterly miſliking marriage, I ſhould giue my daughter to wife, to be in daily diſcord, and vncertaine ſtate of wedlock, to thend that with her trauail, and trooble, I might heale your ſonnes diſeas. You obteyned this at my hands, and I went about it while there was any boote: now it boots not, you muſt therefore beare with me. They ſay, that ſame woman is frée born of this Cittie. She is deliuered of a childe. Séeke to vs no further.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I beſech you for Gods ſake, not to giue your minde to credit thoſe, whoſe greateſt profit groweth by my ſonnes lewdeſt liuing: All this, is but forged and framed for the nones, by reaſon of this marriage: when the cauſe why they do this, is once taken away, Then they will ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You are diceyued, for I my ſelfe ſaw her maide chiding and brawling with Dauus.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I graunt you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nay but in right good earneſt, when as neither of them both was aware of my being there.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I beléeue it well, and that they would do ſo, Dauus fortolde me a prety while ſince, but I wot not how, otherwiſe than I ment, I forgot to tell you ſomuch.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: SIMo hearing by Dauus, that there was one come, which affirmed Glycerie to be free borne of Athens: in a great rage, cauſeth Dauus to be had into priſon faſt bound. And herein, Terence doth liuely expreſſe the vſuall manner both of an angry father, and alſo of an angrie maſter.

sp.p: AT my word, now (at length) ſet your hart at reſt:

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Thus Simo and Chremes do talk betwixt themſelues, & Dauus goeth on ſtill in his ſpeach. Sée where Dauus is.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thus Simo and Chremes do talk betwixt themſelues, & Dauus goeth on ſtill in his ſpeach. Whence comes he?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What thorough my helpe, and yonder ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: He ſpeaketh out of Dauus hearing. What knauery is that?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I haue not ſéene a méeter man, a more ſeaſonable comming, nor a fitter time.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And ſo heere likewiſe. Whome doth this varlet prays thus?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now all is out of danger.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Why doo I linger to ſpeake to him?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now at laſt he eſpyeth Simo. My maſter is here, what ſhall I do.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O, all haill to you honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now maſter, and maſter Chremes, all things be in a redines within.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O it is trimly don of you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now ſend for him when you will.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Very well ſurely: that is the cauſe forſooth he is now abſent: Nay but aunſwere me to this, what buſines haſt thou there? That is in Glyceries houſe

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who, I?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea, you ſirra.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I went in but euen now.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: As though I aſked how long ago it was.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Your ſonne and I went in together.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Why than, and is Pamphilus within? I am ſtill vext vnhappy man that I am. Why thou hangman thou, didſt not thou tell me that they are fallen at debate.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So they are.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What makes he there than?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This is ſpoken in deriſion. What think you that he is a dooing? he is ſure chiding with her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay but maſter Chremes, you ſhall here me tel you of a notable ſtrange matter: I wot not what olde man is come yonder euen now, but to looke to, he is a ſubſtantiall and warie man: if you ſawe his face, you would take him for a right honeſt man. In his countenance is ſad grauitie, and his wordes do ſound of truth.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What tydings bringſt thou?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nothing forſooth but what I hard him ſay.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And what ſaith he, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Mary that he knoweth Glycerie to be a frée born woman of Athens.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Simo calles for him that whips the ſlaues. Hola howh, Dromo, Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Dromo.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why, here me ſir.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: If thou ſpeake one word more—Dromo.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I beſech you here me.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What would you haue ſir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Hoyſe vp this knaue on thy back, and cary him in as faſt as thou canſt.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Dauus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Bycauſe I will haue it ſo, take him away I ſay.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What haue I don ſir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: If you do finde that I told you any lye, kill me furth right.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I will not here one word: I ſhall ſet thée in a beate by and by, I warrant thée.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, notwithſtanding I ſay nothing but Troth?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p:
He ſpeakes to Dromo. Yea neuertheleſſe, ſirra ſée thou that he be kept faſt fetterd: and heareſt thou me? binde his hands and féete together,
He turnes his ſpeach to Dauus and Pamphilus. Now ſir go to: By God if I liue this day to an end, I will teach thée and him both, what danger it is for the one of you to beguile his maſter, and for the other to deceiue his father.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Tuſh man, be not in ſo great a rage.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O Chremes, do you not pitie me, to ſée what reuerend regard my ſonne hath towards me? and that I ſhould take ſomuch trauaill for ſuch a ſonne? Well go to Pamphilus: Come out here Pamphilus, Is there no ſhame in thée?

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: SIMO ſharply rebuketh his ſonne: who confeſſing his fault, ſubmitteth himſelfe wholy vnto his fathers pleaſure, Chremes endeuoreth to appeaſe thextreame Rage of Simo.

sp.p: WHo calles me? O I am vndone, it is my father.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What ſaieſt thou? thou arrand—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Fie, go to the matter, and ceaſe your euill language.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea as though there could be any name to ill for this fellow. Now ſirra, doo you ſay the ſame too? Is Glycerie frée bone of this Citie?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: So it is reported.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: So it is reported? O wonderfull impudency, dooth he conſider what he ſayth, thinke you? is he any thing ſorry for his miſdéede? Nay but ſée, dooth his colour any whit change, or ſhew any ſigne of ſhamefaſtnes? is it meete he ſhould be ſo vnruly, as that contrary to the cuſtome of his cuntrimen, contrary to law, and contrary to the minde of his father, hée doo labour to haue that ſame naughty packe, euen to his vtter infamie and reproche?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Wo is me, forlorne man that I am.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: O Pamphilus, Pamphilus, doſt thou now perceiue that, and neuer before? Long ſince ywis, long ſince, when thou gaueſt thy mynde ſo lewdly, as that by one meane or other thou muſt fulfill thy luſt: lo, euen that very firſt day, had this bin truely ſayd of thée. But what meane I? why do I vexe and diſquiet my ſelfe? why doo I conſume my ſelfe with care? why doo I weare my old age, with ſorrowing for his madnes? is it, that I ſhould ſuffer puniſhment for his faults? Nay rather, let him haue her: and farewell hée: let him liue with her and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: My good father.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What my good father? as who ſhould ſay, you haue any néede of this father: why, you haue got you houſe, and wife, and children, and all maugre your fathers hart. There be alſo thoſe brought, which affirme that ſame quean to be frée borne of this city: wel, you ſhall haue the victory.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Father, may I ſpeake a word or twoo?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What wilt thou ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O Simo, yet heare him.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I heare him Chremes? what ſhould I heare him?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why man, yet geue him leaue to ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Well go too, he may ſpeake, I let hm not.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p:
Father, I confeſſe I loue that ſame woman: and if that be an offence, I confeſſe that alſo. I ſubmit
my ſelfe into your hands father, lay vppon mee what charge you will: commaund me. Is it your pleaſure I ſhould marry a wife? will you haue mée forgo this woman? well, I will beare all as I may. Onely this I beſéech you, not to beléeue that this old man is come hether by my appointment. Geue mee leaue to cléere my ſelfe, and that I may bring the man here before your face.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: That thou maiſt bring him here?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Yea Father, ſuffer. mée.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He craues but reaſon, geue him leaue.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Let me obteine this much at your hands.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I am content. Chremes, I yéeld to any thing, ſo that I finde not my ſelfe to be deceiued by this fellow.

p.hi: Small puniſhment contents a father, for a great offence in his ſonne.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: In this ſcene Crito of Athens meeteth both with Simo and Chremes, wherby the whole error of the comoedy is laid opē: for here, Glycerie is manifeſted to be the doughter of Chremes.

sp.p: CEas to pray me, any one of theſe reſpects, ſhall cauſe mée to doo it: as either for your owne ſake, or for that the matter is truth, or in reſpect that I wiſh well to Glycerie.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
What, is it Crito of Andros that I doo ſée? Truly it is hée indéede. Welcome Crito:
what make you at Athens, being here ſuch a ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: It is ſo fallen out. But is this Simo?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This ſame is hée.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What, is it for mée thou aſkeſt? why ſirra, doſt thou ſay that Glycerie is frée borne of this Citie?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Dooſt thou deny it?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What, and art thou come ſo well prouided indéede.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Aſkeſt thou why? ſhalt thou doo this, and ſcape vnpuniſhed? doſt thou toll here into thy ſnare, yong men voyd of experience, and honeſtly brought vp? Art thou hée that féedeſt furth their mindes with intyſing & faire promiſing?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Abyde, art thou well in thy wits?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And doſt thou make marriages betwixt them and the harlots that they are in loue withall?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: This to himſelfe. Alas I am vndon, I feare me the ſtranger will haue neuer a word to ſay.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Simo, if you knew this man thorowly, you would not think ſo of him: this is an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: May this fellow be an honeſt man? comes he this day ſo iump in the very time of this marriage: and could he come neuer before now? why Chremes, is this a man to bée beléeued?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Were I not afeard of my father, I could tell him that which would ſatiſfie him in this point well ynough.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Hah fogging knaue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O Crito beare with him, this is his faſhon.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p:
Nay let him conſider what he is: As for me, if hée procéede to call mée at his pleaſure, hée ſhall heare that, that ſhall bée litle to his lyking. Doo I let that ſame marriage? or doo I ought at all paſſe
for it?
He turnes his ſpeech to Simo. Thou doſt not beare thy gréefe patiently: for as touching what I ſpake, whether it bée true or falſe that you heard, may ſoone be knowen.

Here is recited the argument of the Comoedie. A certaine man of Athens, a good while ſince, ſuffring Shipwracke, was caſt on ſhore at Andros, together with that ſame Glycerie, as than a little childe. This man being than in néede & neceſſitie: by chaunce firſt arriued at the houſe of Chryſis father.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now he beginnes a fable.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Suffer him to go on.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What, euen ſo indéede? hée interrupts me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Go on with your tale.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Moreouer, hée which receiued him into his houſe, was my Coſin: there did I heare the man himſelfe ſay, that hée was of Athens: and in that houſe he died.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What was his name?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: would you know his name ſo quickly? Phania.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Out alas to day.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In good ſooth, I take it, his name was Phania. This I am well aſſured of, that he ſaid he was a Rhamnus was a famous village by Athens. And Rhamnuſius, 〈◊〉 is a mā of that village. Rhamnuſian.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O the King of heauen.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Yea Chremes, there were than many other in Andros, which hard him ſay the ſame.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Would to God it were no otherwiſe than I hope for. But tell me this Crito, what ſaid he than as touching the girle? dyd hée ſay that ſhée was his doughter?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Whoſe than?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: His brothers doughter.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Without dowt ſhe is myne.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Nay what ſaieſt thou?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Liſten to this geare Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What think you of this?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That ſame Phania was my brother.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I knew the man, and I wot wel he was your brother.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He flying hence, for feare of the warre, takes his way after me into Aſia, and than he was afraid to leaue her here behind him. Since which time, I neuer hard what became of him till now.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I am well nigh beſide my ſelfe, my minde is ſo whelmed, with feare, hope, Ioy, and with wondring at ſo great, and ſo ſodeyn good hap.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Now in good faith, I am glad that by many proofs ſhe is found to be your daughter.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Father I beléeue it well.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But there remaines yet one doubt, which ſore troubles me.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: You are well worthie to be hated for your péeuiſh preciſenes: you make a doubt where all is as plaine as a pack ſtaf.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What is that you doubt of?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Her name falles not out right.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Truly ſhe had an other name, when ſhe was a childe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What name? Cannot you remember it Crito?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I am calling it to minde.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Shall I ſuffer this mans memory to be a hinderance vnto my wiſhed ioy, when as I may helpe my ſelfe in this point? no, I will not ſuffer it. Lo you heare Cremes, the name you ſéeke for, is Paſsibula.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That ſame is ſhe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Is it euen ſhe.

sp.speaker: Pamp.
sp.p: ſhe hath told it me her own ſelf a thouſād times.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Chremes, I wene you beleue that we all reioyce at this.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yea ſo God me help, doo I beleue it.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Father, what remaines now to be don?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: The matter it ſelfe hath reconciled me a good while ſince.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: O an excellent father. Chremes altereth nothing as touching my wife, but that I may ſtill enioy her, as I haue don.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Mary and good cauſe why. Vnleſſe your father ſay otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Onely, as touching the dowry.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yea marry, that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pamphilus her dowry is fiue hundered pound.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I accept it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I will now hye me to my daughter, and you Crito, go with me: for I beleue ſhe neuer knew me.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: And why doo you not rather cauſe her to be brought hether to you?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: You put vs well in minde, I will preſently cauſe Dauus to go about that matter.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: He cannot.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Mary bycauſe he hath a great matter of his own, which toucheth him néerer.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: He lieth bound in priſon.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Father, then is he wrongfully bound.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Not ſo, I commaunded it.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I beſeche you, command that he be let looſe.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Go to, be it ſo.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: But make haſt than.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I go in ſtraight way.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: O Bliſfull and happy day that this is.

argument.head: The Argument.
argument.p: PAMPHILVS declareth vnto Dauus, how that Glycerie is found to be free borne of Athens, & that he ſhall marry her Likewiſe Carinus ſheweth vnto Pamphilus, that by his meanes, he alſo may obtaine Philumena at Chremes hands. This Scene brings an other ſonne in law to Chremes: leaſt that either Carinus ſhould depart away ſorowfull, or that Philumena ſhould be left vnprouided for.

sp.p: I I am come furth, to ſée what Pamphilus is a doing: but lo where he is.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Perhaps ſome body would think that I ſkant beleue this to be true, but I will haue it to be true, as it is in déede. I ſuppoſe that therefore the lyfe of the Gods is euerlaſting, bycauſe pleaſures do properly belong vnto them: for mine own part, I am in heauen al redy, if ſo be it, no griefe of minde doo intermingle with this ioy. But now what man ſhould I moſt ſpecially deſire to méete withall, to whome I might ſhew all that hath happened.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This to himſelfe. What great ioy is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Lo, I ſee Dauus: There is no man liuing that I would fayner haue: for I am ſure that he, of all other, will vnfainedly reioyce at my ioy and gladneſſe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: whereabout here, is Pamphilus?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Dauus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What man is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: It is I.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: O my maſter Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Thou wotſt not what hath hapned to me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Very true, but I wot well what hath hapned to my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: And ſo doo I too.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yea it came to pas after the common courſe of the world, that you knew of the euil that hapned to me, ſooner than I knew of the good that hapned to you.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: My ſwéete loue Glycerie, hath found out who be her parents.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: O happy chaunce.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This he ſaith to himſelfe. What is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Her father is a very ſpeciall frend of ours.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Chremes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You ſay well.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Neither is there any let or tariance, but that I may marry her out of hand.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This is ſpoken out of the hearing of Pamphilus. What, doth he not dreame trow you, that which his minde ran vpon being awake?

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: Now moreouer Dauus, as touching the childe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Tuſh let it alone, God doth ſpecially prouide for it aboue all other children.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Carinus is ouer heard by Pamphilus. I am a made man, if this be true: I will ſure ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What man is there? O Carinus, you come to me, euen as well as heart can wiſh.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It is well.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: What, haue you heard the matter?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes euery whit: Go to, haue ſome reſpect of me, now in the time of your proſperitie: I know that Chremes is now yours altogether, and will doo all that you will haue him doo.

sp.speaker: Pamph.
sp.p: I wot it full well: but it would be too long for vs, to tarry and looke for his comming furth:
Therefore follow me along this way: he is now within with Glicerie. Dauus go thou thy way home: hye thée, go for company to bring her away hence. Why doſt thou ſtand ſtill? why goeſt thou not?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I am going.

This ſeems not to he ſpoken by any of the interloquutors, but by ſome other comming laſt on the ſtage. Do not ſtay looking for their comming out: for ſhée ſhall be betrothed within: and if any thing more remaine to be don, it ſhall bée diſpatcht within alſo.
Now clap hands, and reioyce.

argument.p: Here is to be vnderſtood that as Pamphilus hath Glycerie to wife: Euen ſo Carinus likewiſe hath Philumena, the other Doughter of Chremes.
